resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
pachamaltese opened a new pull request #9797:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9797


   Hi
   
   I have used the same setup that I used when I worked in finance, this is to call `R  --vanilla` from the terminal, and use the global CRAN  repository, so that this fix applies to Windows/Mac/Linux.
   
   The changes made solve the following problems:
   - Packages not installing because the default mirror is not found
   - The lack of packages bit64 and tidyselect
   
   Best,
   


--

ianmcook commented on a change in pull request #9797:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9797#discussion_r600789692



##########
File path: r/README.md
##########
@@ -143,7 +143,15 @@ checkout:
 
 ``` shell
 cd ../../r
-R -e 'install.packages(c("devtools", "roxygen2", "pkgdown", "covr")); devtools::install_dev_deps()'
+
+R --vanilla << EOF
+options(repos = c(REPO_NAME = "https://cloud.r-project.org/"))
+install.packages(c("bit64", "devtools", "roxygen2", "tidyselect",
+ "pkgdown", "covr") 

Review comment:
       This is missing a `)`




--

       ```suggestion
   options(repos = "https://cloud.r-project.org/")
   ```

##########
File path: r/README.md
##########
@@ -143,7 +143,15 @@ checkout:
 
 ``` shell
 cd ../../r
-R -e 'install.packages(c("devtools", "roxygen2", "pkgdown", "covr")); devtools::install_dev_deps()'
+
+R --vanilla << EOF
+options(repos = c(REPO_NAME = "https://cloud.r-project.org/"))
+install.packages(c("bit64", "devtools", "roxygen2", "tidyselect",

Review comment:
       bit64 and tidyselect are hard dependencies of arrow so you don't need to install them explicitly
   
   None of the other dependencies are required to build the package, and they bring a lot of stuff with them, so it's probably better to leave them off as a separate step.
   
   The quickest version of this is `install.packages("remotes"); remotes::install_deps(dependencies = TRUE)`

##########

+
+R --vanilla << EOF

Review comment:
       I think it's also confusing; I'd go back to the one-liner, that wasn't the problem.

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.summary: [R][Docs] Fix install.packages command in R dev docs

comments.body:
I think this by-and-large has been resolved by https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/pull/73315, but we should probably add a bit of content that mentions the (now less likely) possible failure modes for people not familiar with R:

* at least mention that one might need to set a cran mirror if one hasn't before
* that if installing the dependencies from source fails there are likely config messages in the scrollback that can help (most packages that fail because some system dependency isn't present say that, though the place that that is in the logs isn't a helpful one and it's usually waaaay up in the scrollback)
* maybe pare back what we install to only {devtools} or possibly only install {remotes} with {{remotes::install_deps(dependencies = TRUE)}} since remotes has significantly fewer dependencies

Hi
This is closely related to the problems I saw today when building on Linux.
I have no idea about brew, but there' s a way to make this system-wide. I shall send a PR now with a long comment.

I have created a PR: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9797
This is the detail: 
_I have used the same setup that I used when I worked in finance, this is to call R --vanilla from the terminal, and use the global CRAN repository, so that this fix applies to Windows/Mac/Linux._

_The changes made solve the following problems:_
* _Packages not installing because the default mirror is not found_
* _The lack of packages bit64 and tidyselect_
